title: 108_s501
content: The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" establishes a grant program for gifted and talented students under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This program authorizes activities to support gifted and talented students. The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" recognizes the need for specialized services for gifted students from diverse backgrounds, including those with disabilities or English as a second language. It acknowledges that these students have already mastered a significant portion of the curriculum before the school year begins. Teachers are faced with a wide range of student traits and needs in their classrooms. Before the school year begins, talented students have already mastered a significant portion of the curriculum. Teachers receive training to meet the needs of students with disabilities, limited English proficiency, and diverse backgrounds, but often lack training for gifted students. Public schools are the main resource for high-ability students, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds. Gifted education programs are essential for these students and should be provided by qualified professionals. Gifted education programs in public schools are crucial for high-ability students, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds. Parents and families play a vital role in developing appropriate educational services for gifted students. There is currently no federal requirement to identify or serve the nation's approximately 3,000,000 gifted students, although some states and local agencies allocate resources for this purpose. To address the disparity in gifted education, it is crucial for more students to achieve higher levels of education. The performance of twelfth-grade advanced students in the United States on international assessments is among the lowest globally, highlighting the need for improved educational opportunities for highly capable students. The performance of twelfth-grade advanced students in the United States on international assessments is among the lowest globally, emphasizing the need for improved educational opportunities for highly capable students. In 1990, only a small fraction of education funding was allocated to challenging programs for gifted students. If the appropriated amount exceeds $7,500,000 but is less than $57,500,000, competitive grants may be awarded to states for this purpose. The Secretary may award grants to State educational agencies for developing or expanding gifted and talented education programs if the appropriated amount exceeds $7,500,000 but is less than $57,500,000. The State educational agencies receive grants from section 5467B to fund gifted and talented education programs for local educational agencies. Grant funds can be used for activities like providing direct educational services to gifted students and using emerging technologies for curriculum development. Grant funds provided under this chapter for activities like curriculum development through emerging technologies may not be used for purchasing or upgrading technological hardware. State educational agencies receiving grants must not use more than 10 percent of the funds for dissemination of program information, technical assistance, monitoring, evaluation, parental education support, or other specified activities. The State educational agency can use grant funds for activities like technical assistance, monitoring, parental education support, and creating a State gifted education advisory board. Up to 50 percent of the funds can be used for administrative costs. "SEC. 5467A. ALLOTMENTS TO STATES." The Secretary reserves funds for programs in schools operated or funded by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The total amount available is allotted to states based on their populations of individuals aged 5 through 17. States must receive a minimum grant amount, and any unclaimed funds are reallocated to other states. "SEC. 5467B. State application." To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with assurances that funds will support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, be used for grants to local educational agencies, supplement existing funds, and provide matching funds. The State educational agency must use funds to supplement, not supplant, state and local funds for gifted and talented students, provide matching funds of at least 10%, and develop program assessment models for accountability and effectiveness. The Secretary will approve state applications that meet the requirements of this chapter. The State educational agency must allocate at least 90% of funds to local educational agencies through a competitive process for grants to carry out authorized activities. Grants should be sufficient to meet the needs of students. Local educational agencies must submit an application to the State educational agency to receive a grant under this chapter. The application must include assurances that funds will be used to support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, a plan to meet their educational needs, and a commitment to supplement existing funds for these students. The Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003 requires annual reporting by State educational agencies on the number of students served and activities supported with funds. The act allows serving gifted students alongside those with similar needs and ensures participation of private school students and teachers. Definitions are also provided. The Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003 requires reporting by State educational agencies on students served and activities supported with funds. The act defines 'gifted and talented' and 'State'. Authorization of Appropriations: $170,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2004 through 2010. $7,500,000 is allocated for chapter A, with the remainder for chapter 2. Technical amendments are made to the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program. Technical and conforming amendments are made to the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program, including changes to subpart 6 of part D of title V of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This includes renaming the subpart as "Chapter A--Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program" and adjusting references from "this part" to "this chapter." Subsection (c) is removed from section 5464, with subsections (d) and (e) being redesignated as subsections (c) and (d), respectively.
